thig2.3:1.2: Both _musala_ and “pestle” derive from roots “to pound”. I think this whole verse hinges on double innuendos of kitchen drudgery and sex.
thig2.3:1.3: Accepting the commentary’s idea that _ahiriko_ refers to the husband. Read _vāti_; according to pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:10.21.7 wind is a cause of erections. _chattakaṁ_ could be either “mushroom” (sprouting up) or an umbrella (being opened). I choose to retain the kitchen imagery.
thig2.3:1.4: In pli-tv-bi-vb-pc5 Mahapajapati stands downwind due to supposed vaginal odors.
